source.934af4b5:
# Cargamos los datos de entrenamiento y test
test_data = pd.read_csv("../input/titanic/test.csv").fillna("")
train_data = pd.read_csv("../input/titanic/train.csv").fillna("")

train_data.head()
source.889faded:
# Exploramos los datos
women = train_data.loc[train_data.Sex == 'female']["Survived"]
rate_women = sum(women)/len(women)
men = train_data.loc[train_data.Sex == 'male']["Survived"]
rate_men = sum(men)/len(men)

print("% of men who survived:", round(rate_men,1)*100,"%")
print("% of women who survived:", round(rate_women,1)*100,"%")
source.d6459fcb:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
# from sklearn.ensemble import BaggingRegressor
from sklearn.neighbors import KNeighborsClassifier


y = train_data["Survived"]

features = ["Pclass", "Sex", "SibSp", "Parch"]
X = pd.get_dummies(train_data[features])
X_test = pd.get_dummies(test_data[features])

model =  KNeighborsClassifier(n_neighbors=5)
model.fit(X, y)
predictions = model.predict(X_test)
#model.score(predictions, y_test)
source.e60517fe:
output = pd.DataFrame({'PassengerId': test_data.PassengerId, 'Survived': predictions})
output.to_csv('mi_prediccion.csv', index=False)
print("Mi predicción ha sido grabada :)!")
source.c831669b: Vemos que hay un diferencias entre hombres y mujeres respecto a quién vive. La variable Sexo luego podría identificar y ser buen predictor para el modelo. La muejeres tiene una mayor propoporción (70%) de supervivencia que los hombres (20%)
